On Véron’s Manuale Sodalitatis, designed for the use of students in Jesuit colleges, see Thomson, “Loyola et Descartes,” 61–9. Another text in widespread use in Jesuit schools and sodalities as well as by private individuals all over Catholic central Europe was the Calendarium novum ad bene moriendum perquam utile, first published in 1665 and reprinted well into the eighteenth century. It includes a cycle of meditational readings, one for each day of the month; the readings for the third through the eighth days cover the last things
